attributes.title: An Essential Service Decision Model for Applied Behavior Analytic Providers During Crisis
attributes.description: In the United States, applied behavior analysis (ABA) is broadly recognized as a medically necessary treatment for individuals diagnosed with autism and related disorders (Association of Professional Behavior Analysts, 2020). We argue that this designation should not be called into question in the light of a particular disaster and that it is critical to consider that an interruption of services can have long-lasting effects on the treatment of the individual (practitioners are ethically obligated to uphold the continuity of services while doing no harm). This dilemma might be ameliorated by a decision model that considers the prioritization of immediate needs, vulnerability of clients, and competency of service providers. Just as the medical field prioritizes immediate needs during crisis situations and defers routine appointments (e.g., physicals, check-ups, etc.), the ABA field can make similar evidence-based decisions. The purpose of the current paper is to provide a decision model for ABA practitioners who find themselves questioning the need for essential service delivery during the current Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The impact of this model goes beyond the needs of this crisis and can be applied to any emergency situation where services are at risk of interruption.

attributes.title: Longitudinal association between maternal autonomy support and adolescents’ depressive symptoms.
attributes.description: This two-wave longitudinal study is part of a project exploring the key determinants of adolescents’ psychological well-being. A growing body of research has suggested that parents who interact with their adolescents in ways that support the latter’s experience of autonomy are particularly effective in supporting adaptive psychological functioning (Chirkov & Ryan, 2001; Ferguson et al., 2011). We aim to investigate the longitudinal influence of maternal autonomy support and controlling parenting, which is measured by both mothers’ self-reports and adolescents’ perception, on the depressive symptoms in adolescents. We also aim to investigate the mediating role of basic psychological need satisfaction in the link between both autonomy support and controlling parenting and depressive symptoms.

q1.value: Ayumi Tanaka, Noriaki Fukuzumi, Ryo Ishii, Shin-ichi Ishikawa, Naoki Nakazato, Kazuhiro Ohtani, Michiko Sakaki, Takashi Suzuki, Ayame Tamura, Kou Murayama

q2.value:
1. Mothers’ reported autonomy support and controlling parenting predicts adolescents’ perceived autonomy support and controlling parenting. Specifically, mothers’ reported autonomy support is related positively with adolescents’ perceived autonomy support, and negatively with perceived controlling parenting. Mothers’ reported controlling parenting is related negatively with adolescents’ perceived autonomy support, and positively with perceived controlling parenting.
2. Adolescents’ perceived autonomy support predicts their basic psychological need satisfaction. Specifically, adolescents’ perceived autonomy support is related positively and perceived controlling parenting is related negatively with basic psychological need satisfaction. 
3. Adolescents’ basic psychological need satisfaction predicts their depressive symptoms. Specifically, adolescents’ basic psychological need satisfaction is related negatively with depressive symptoms.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Longitudinal observational study with two time points.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: Data for the first time point (T1) of the study were already collected in 2019; however, we do not have access to them yet. Data from the second time point (T2) have not been fully collected. We will gain access to the entire dataset once the T2 data are collected.

question.value: Participants were recruited from a large nationwide database managed by the Japan Management Association, a private research firm. Participants were randomly selected from different parts of Japan, with no regional restrictions. Children needed to be between 13 and 15 years of age. Participants were mailed their first questionnaire in October 2019 (T1) and asked to return it after completion. They were mailed a second questionnaire in February–March 2020 (T2) to be returned once completed. Mothers and adolescents were instructed to complete their questionnaire independently and to not look at each other’s answers. All participants received monetary compensation from the firm for their participation.

q11.value: The sample size was fixed at 350 mother–child dyads (700 individuals) for the T1.

q12.value: The sample size was chosen based on the funding received to conduct the study. We also considered the possible loss to follow up of participants between the two time points. Based on our previous study, we expected an attrition rate of 25% between T1 and T2, which would give us an anticipated total of 260 dyads at T2.

question.value:
1. Maternal autonomy support and control. 
Mothers reported their own autonomy-supportive or controlling practices with their adolescent by filling out a Japanese translation of the Perceived Parental Autonomy Support Scale (Mageau et al., 2015) at T1 and T2. Adolescents reported their perception of their Mother’s Autonomy Support (12-items) and Controlling Parenting (12 items) by filling out the same questionnaire at T1 and T2.  The items are rated on a seven-point Likert scale from “1=do not agree at all” to “7=very strongly agree.”

2. Depressive symptoms.
Adolescents reported their level of depressive symptoms by filling out the short version of the Depression Self-Rating Scale for Children (Namikawa et al., 2011) at T1 and T2. The scale is composed of two subscales: Decreased Enjoyment and Activities (5 items) and Depressive Mood (4 items). The responses are rated on a three-point Likert scale ranging from “1=not at all” to “3=always.”

3. Basic psychological need satisfaction. 
Adolescents reported their level of basic psychological need satisfaction by filling out the satisfaction subscale from the Japanese version of the Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (Nishimura & Suzuki, 2016) at T1 and T2. The scale contains four items for the satisfaction of each basic psychological need: Autonomy, Competence, and Relatedness. The responses are rated on a five-point Likert scale ranging from “1=completely disagree” to “5=completely agree.”

4. Parent–child relationship satisfaction. 
Mothers and adolescents reported the extent to which they are satisfied with their relationship with each other at T1 and T2. The two items from Lin, Chen, & Li (2013) are rated on a five-point Likert scale ranging from “1 = completely disagree” to “5=completely agree.”

5. Family socioeconomic status. Mothers reported the annual income of the family at T1.

6. Sex. Parents and adolescents reported their own sex at T1.

7. Age. Parents and adolescents reported their age at T1.

For the measure of depressive symptoms, we will combine the decreased enjoyment and activities subscale and the depressive mood subscale to create a single measure. We will also combine the scores for the autonomy, competence, and relatedness subscales to create a single measure of Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction.

We will run cross-lagged models with mediations, in which mothers’ reported autonomy support will predict adolescents’ depressive symptoms. The mediation analyses in our cross-lagged models will test the mediation effect of adolescents’ perceived autonomy support and basic psychological need satisfaction on the associations between mothers’ reported autonomy support and adolescents’ depressive symptoms.
We will follow the analytic strategy of running mediation analyses in two-wave datasets, as described by Cole and Maxwell (2003) and Little et al. (2007). We will control for mothers and adolescents reported parent–child relationship satisfaction, family socioeconomic status, age, and sex of adolescents.

q19.value: To judge the significance of our beta values, we will use the standard .05 threshold for p-values.

q23.value:
Since this study is part of larger project, we will share some of the data from the study (registered as /ba6kg) with other researchers.

Cole, D. A., & Maxwell, S. E. (2003). Testing mediational models with longitudinal data: Questions and tips in the use of structural equation modeling. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 112(4), 558–577. https://doi.org/10.1037/0021-843X.112.4.558.

attributes.title: Weakening the Ideological Immune System: Can Debiasing Techniques Reduce Confirmation Bias?
attributes.description: Psychologists have identified confirmation bias as a significant obstacle to rational decision making. Given the role of confirmation bias in exacerbating conflict and ideological extremism, the development of cognitive debiasing techniques seems worthwhile. However, the efficacy of social science’s existing arsenal of debiasing techniques remains largely unknown, and the extant positive findings have often been inconsistent and in need of independent replication. In this proposed registered report, we aim to empirically test the efficacy of three cognitive debiasing techniques in mitigating confirmation bias: consider-the-opposite, psychoeducation, and a novel social norms manipulation. Being able to compare these strategies will have the benefit of providing theoretical advancement by shedding light on the processes that give rise to confirmation bias. Moreover, these results will help in identifying the most promising techniques to serve as the foundation for debiasing interventions.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
1.	Debiasing Condition: (consider-the-opposite vs. social norms vs. psychoeducation vs. control)

Participants assigned to the consider-the-opposite debiasing technique will be asked to generate two reasons why a person may have an attitude that conflicts with their own (Hoch, 1985). Participants assigned to the social norms condition will do nothing at this time, but, during the selective exposure (article selection) portion of the experiment, they will learn that a high proportion of people who share their original attitude chose to read attitude-inconsistent essays (Adams et al., 2018). Participants assigned to the psychoeducation condition will read an excerpt from an undergraduate psychology textbook that explains the concept of cognitive bias and provides descriptions of confirmation bias, hindsight bias, and the availability heuristic. Participants in the control condition will read an excerpt from an undergraduate psychology textbook that explains the concept of an attitude and provides descriptions of cognitive, affective, and behavioral components of attitudes.

a.	between-participants 
b. N/A 

2.	Article Type: (belief-consistent vs. belief inconsistent)

Participants will be asked to select articles that they would like to read. Half of the articles presented will be consistent with the attitude expressed by the participant, and the other half will be inconsistent with the attitude expressed by the participant. 

a.	within-participants 
b.	b. N/A

question2b.value:
DV: 
1.	Selective exposure – number of articles selected
2.	Biased assimilation – study evaluation ratings
3.	Selective exposure – reading time

question10b.value:
The proposed study will utilize a two-way mixed ANOVA with one within-subjects factor and one between-groups factor. Article type (belief consistent vs. belief inconsistent); debiasing technique is the between-subjects factor (consider-the-opposite vs. social norms vs. psychoeducation vs. control). The dependent variables will be selective exposure (assessed via article selection and reading time; see below) and biased assimilation. To reduce the possibility that our results are specific to one topic area, we will also include topic as a between-subjects variable (topic areas: immigration, physician-assisted suicide, abortion, power of the federal government, and views on the U.S. petroleum industry). We will not advance hypotheses concerning comparisons between topic areas, although we will report such comparisons in exploratory analyses. We have selected these five topic areas because we believe they cover a breadth of issues, and they are well-known enough that participants are likely to have some opinion on them. 

Participants will only be assigned to a topic area if they respond with sum of 3-9 or 15-21 for that topic. Specifically, we will identify the topics for which a participant gives a non-moderate response, and randomly assign that participant to one of those topics. If a participant does not respond with a non-moderate response to any of the five topics, they will be sent directly to the end of the study.

If not sent to the end, participants will then be asked to, in the following order, complete attention check, select articles to read (selective exposure – article selection), complete manipulation checks, evaluate research studies (biased assimilation), and read the articles they selected previously (selective exposure – reading time). Then, participants will be asked to report their attitude toward the relevant topic area once more. Finally, participants will be asked to complete measures of intellectual humility and asked to report their demographic information.

question4b.value:
Participants will be required to be 18+ years old, and they must be enrolled in classes at the University of Alabama or Emory University. 

In order to ensure that we get a balance of both starting attitudes (pro and anti) for each of the five topic areas, we will aim to collect at least 30 pro participants and 30 anti participants for each of our five topic areas within each condition (see Table 1; topic areas: immigration, physician-assisted suicide, abortion, power of the federal government, and views on the U.S. petroleum industry). To assess attitudes toward each topic, we will ask participants respond to three different questions (e.g., To what extent do you agree that current immigration laws in the U.S. are too strict?). Responses will be made using a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 2 = moderately disagree, 3 = slightly disagree, 4 = neither agree nor disagree, 5 = slightly agree, 6 = moderately agree, 7 = strongly agree). For each topic area, responses to the three attitude questions will be summed (i.e., participants will have scores ranging from 3 – 21). Because confirmation bias can only be meaningfully assessed when a person has a non-moderate opinion on a topic, participants will only be recruited for a topic group if they respond with a summed score of 3-9 or 15-21, indicating a polarized attitude on the issue. Participants who respond moderately (i.e., in the range of scores from 10-14) for all five topic areas will be sent directly to the end of the study.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited from undergraduate psychology participant pool at the University of Alabama and Emory University. Data will be collected online using an online Qualtrics Survey.

question6b.value: Because relying on previous literature to determine an anticipated effect size is likely to provide an overestimate (Ioannidis, 2008) and the average effect size in published social psychology research is d = .43 (Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003), we aimed to achieve enough power to detect a much smaller effect (f = .10) because we expect a partial attenuation interaction (i.e., it is more likely, if one of the interventions works, that the intervention would reduce selective exposure and biased assimilation rather than eliminating them). The following power analysis references a series of comparisons with experimental vs. control analyses that are likely to be directionally similar confirmation biases. That is, the power analysis is not for the full 2 x 4 mixed ANOVA design but for comparing two groups: a 2 (A 2 (Debiasing Technique: Control vs. Consider the Opposite [social norms] [psychoeducation]) x 2 (Article Type: Belief Inconsistent vs. Belief Consistent) mixed model ANOVA. To achieve 95% power for detecting an effect of f = .10 using a two-way mixed ANOVA, conservatively assuming a correlation of r = 0.15 between the repeated measures, 278 participants per group are required. We plan to overshoot this number slightly to allow for anticipated participant exclusions, and thus will aim to collect at least 300 participants per debiasing condition (1200 total).

question7b.value: Data collection will be terminated once at least 30 pro and 30 anti participants have been recruited for each topic area within each condition (see Table 1). We expect to exceed this goal slightly for some cells because of changes in participants attitudes from the pre-screening measure, and because of instances where an n is reached but there remain unfilled slots that were previously posted.

question1a.value:
1.	Describe each of the hypotheses in terms of directional relationships between your variables.  
The proposed study will examine five research questions: 
RQ1. Do participants show a confirmation bias effect (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation) in the absence of debiasing strategies? 
RQ2. Does the consider-the-opposite debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ3. Does the social norm debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ4. Does the psychoeducation debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ5. Do the three strategies differ in magnitudes of their effects on confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?

question3a.value: To test the consider-the-opposite manipulation, participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they can understand how someone could hold an attitude opposite to their own. To test the social norms manipulation, participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they think that an average participant, a participant who shares their belief, and a participant who does not share their belief would be willing to read articles that are inconsistent with their views. To test the psychoeducation manipulation, participants will be asked to answer one short multiple-choice question quizzing them on the concept of confirmation bias. Responses given by participants in the relevant debiasing condition will be compared to those given by participants in the control condition to determine the efficacy of each manipulation.

question1c.value:
Selective exposure: Article selection. Once participants have completed the debiasing task, they will be asked to choose news articles that they would be interested in reading about their given topic. Participants will be given a choice between six different news articles: three that are consistent with their reported belief and three that are inconsistent. All participants will be required to select a minimum of one article, but there will be no set maximum (i.e., participants can opt to read all six of the articles). An article selection score will be calculated by recording the number of belief-inconsistent articles that the participant chose and the number of belief-consistent articles they chose. Article selection scores will be collapsed across the five topic areas for all analyses.

Biased assimilation. Next, participants will be asked to evaluate two research study summaries, one in support of their topic and one against (e.g., one demonstrating the benefits of legalizing abortion and one challenging legalization). The order of presentation will be randomized so that some participants will read the belief-consistent study first and others the belief-inconsistent study. We will then ask participants to rate the quality and believability of each study’s results, with higher scores indicating more favorable ratings. A biased assimilation score will be calculated by recording ratings of belief-inconsistent studies and ratings of belief-consistent studies. Biased assimilation scores will be collapsed across the five topic areas for all analyses. 

Selective exposure: Reading time. Participants will be given an opportunity to read the articles that they selected previously, and as an index of selective exposure, we will measure the amount of time participants spend reading each article. A reading time score will be calculated by subtracting reading time for belief-inconsistent articles from reading time for belief-consistent articles. Higher scores indicate greater selective exposure. Reading time scores will be collapsed across the three topic areas for all analyses.

question2c.value:
Baseline confirmation bias (RQ1). To examine whether we observed a confirmation bias effect in the absence of debiasing strategies, we will examine selective exposure and biased assimilation among participants in the control condition. 
First, we will conduct a dependent t-test, comparing article selection scores for belief-consistent and belief-inconsistent articles. 
Then, we will conduct a dependent t-test comparing biased assimilation scores for belief-consistent and belief-inconsistent articles.
Finally, we will conduct a one-sample t-test comparing reading time scores to 0.

question3c.value:
IV: Article Type (Belief-consistent vs. belief-inconsistent)
DVs: Selective Exposure (article selection and reading time), Biased Assimilation

question1c.value:
Selective exposure: Article selection. Once participants have completed the debiasing task, they will be asked to choose news articles that they would be interested in reading about their given topic. Participants will be given a choice between six different news articles: three that are consistent with their reported belief and three that are inconsistent. All participants will be required to select a minimum of one article, but there will be no set maximum (i.e., participants can opt to read all six of the articles). An article selection score will be calculated by recording the number of belief-inconsistent articles that the participant chose and the number of belief-consistent articles they chose. Article selection scores will be collapsed across the five topic areas for all analyses.

Biased assimilation. question2c.value:
Comparing the efficacy of debiasing strategies (RQ5). To examine whether the debiasing conditions differed in their effects, we will compare selective exposure and biased assimilation across the three experimental conditions (consider-the-opposite, social norms, psychoeducation). 
First, we will conduct a 3 x 2 mixed model ANOVA comparing article selection scores across the three conditions.  To test if the effect of article type is moderated by debiasing technique, we will conduct three 2 x 2 ANOVAs: 1) First, we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the consider-the-opposite and social norms conditions; 2) Second, we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the consider-the-opposite and psychoeducation conditions; 3) we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the psychoeducation and social norms conditions.
Then, we will conduct a 3 x 2 mixed model ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores across the three conditions. To test if the effect of study type is moderated by debiasing technique, we will conduct three 2 x 2 ANOVAs: 1) First, we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the consider-the-opposite and social norms conditions; 2) Second, we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the consider-the-opposite and psychoeducation conditions; 3) we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the psychoeducation and social norms conditions.
Finally, we will conduct a one-way omnibus ANOVA comparing reading time scores across the three conditions.  [Note: we will only conduct the following planned contrasts if the one-way ANOVA is significant]. A planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the consider-the-opposite vs. social norms condition; a planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the consider-the-opposite vs. psychoeducation condition; a planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the social norms vs. psychoeducation condition.

DVs: Selective Exposure (article selection and reading time), Biased Assimilation

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1.	Describe each of the hypotheses in terms of directional relationships between your variables.  
The proposed study will examine five research questions: 
RQ1. Do participants show a confirmation bias effect (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation) in the absence of debiasing strategies? 
RQ2. Does the consider-the-opposite debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ3. Does the social norm debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ4. Does the psychoeducation debiasing strategy reduce confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
RQ5. Do the three strategies differ in magnitudes of their effects on confirmation bias (i.e., selective exposure and biased assimilation)?
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: To test the consider-the-opposite manipulation, participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they can understand how someone could hold an attitude opposite to their own. To test the social norms manipulation, participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they think that an average participant, a participant who shares their belief, and a participant who does not share their belief would be willing to read articles that are inconsistent with their views. To test the psychoeducation manipulation, participants will be asked to answer one short multiple-choice question quizzing them on the concept of confirmation bias. Responses given by participants in the relevant debiasing condition will be compared to those given by participants in the control condition to determine the efficacy of each manipulation.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
1.	Debiasing Condition: (consider-the-opposite vs. social norms vs. psychoeducation vs. control)

Participants assigned to the consider-the-opposite debiasing technique will be asked to generate two reasons why a person may have an attitude that conflicts with their own (Hoch, 1985). Participants assigned to the social norms condition will do nothing at this time, but, during the selective exposure (article selection) portion of the experiment, they will learn that a high proportion of people who share their original attitude chose to read attitude-inconsistent essays (Adams et al., 2018). Participants assigned to the psychoeducation condition will read an excerpt from an undergraduate psychology textbook that explains the concept of cognitive bias and provides descriptions of confirmation bias, hindsight bias, and the availability heuristic. Participants in the control condition will read an excerpt from an undergraduate psychology textbook that explains the concept of an attitude and provides descriptions of cognitive, affective, and behavioral components of attitudes.

a.	between-participants 
b. N/A 

2.	Article Type: (belief-consistent vs. belief inconsistent)

Participants will be asked to select articles that they would like to read. Half of the articles presented will be consistent with the attitude expressed by the participant, and the other half will be inconsistent with the attitude expressed by the participant. 

a.	within-participants 
b.	b. N/A

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
The proposed study will utilize a two-way mixed ANOVA with one within-subjects factor and one between-groups factor. Article type (belief consistent vs. belief inconsistent); debiasing technique is the between-subjects factor (consider-the-opposite vs. social norms vs. psychoeducation vs. control). The dependent variables will be selective exposure (assessed via article selection and reading time; see below) and biased assimilation. To reduce the possibility that our results are specific to one topic area, we will also include topic as a between-subjects variable (topic areas: immigration, physician-assisted suicide, abortion, power of the federal government, and views on the U.S. petroleum industry). We will not advance hypotheses concerning comparisons between topic areas, although we will report such comparisons in exploratory analyses. We have selected these five topic areas because we believe they cover a breadth of issues, and they are well-known enough that participants are likely to have some opinion on them. 

Participants will only be assigned to a topic area if they respond with sum of 3-9 or 15-21 for that topic. Specifically, we will identify the topics for which a participant gives a non-moderate response, and randomly assign that participant to one of those topics. If a participant does not respond with a non-moderate response to any of the five topics, they will be sent directly to the end of the study.

If not sent to the end, participants will then be asked to, in the following order, complete attention check, select articles to read (selective exposure – article selection), complete manipulation checks, evaluate research studies (biased assimilation), and read the articles they selected previously (selective exposure – reading time). Then, participants will be asked to report their attitude toward the relevant topic area once more. Finally, participants will be asked to complete measures of intellectual humility and asked to report their demographic information.

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest:
Participants will be required to be 18+ years old, and they must be enrolled in classes at the University of Alabama or Emory University. 

In order to ensure that we get a balance of both starting attitudes (pro and anti) for each of the five topic areas, we will aim to collect at least 30 pro participants and 30 anti participants for each of our five topic areas within each condition (see Table 1; topic areas: immigration, physician-assisted suicide, abortion, power of the federal government, and views on the U.S. petroleum industry). To assess attitudes toward each topic, we will ask participants respond to three different questions (e.g., To what extent do you agree that current immigration laws in the U.S. are too strict?). Responses will be made using a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 2 = moderately disagree, 3 = slightly disagree, 4 = neither agree nor disagree, 5 = slightly agree, 6 = moderately agree, 7 = strongly agree). For each topic area, responses to the three attitude questions will be summed (i.e., participants will have scores ranging from 3 – 21). Because confirmation bias can only be meaningfully assessed when a person has a non-moderate opinion on a topic, participants will only be recruited for a topic group if they respond with a summed score of 3-9 or 15-21, indicating a polarized attitude on the issue. Participants who respond moderately (i.e., in the range of scores from 10-14) for all five topic areas will be sent directly to the end of the study.
Participants will be recruited from undergraduate psychology participant pool at the University of Alabama and Emory University. Data will be collected online using an online Qualtrics Survey.

Because relying on previous literature to determine an anticipated effect size is likely to provide an overestimate (Ioannidis, 2008) and the average effect size in published social psychology research is d = .43 (Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003), we aimed to achieve enough power to detect a much smaller effect (f = .10) because we expect a partial attenuation interaction (i.e., it is more likely, if one of the interventions works, that the intervention would reduce selective exposure and biased assimilation rather than eliminating them). The following power analysis references a series of comparisons with experimental vs. control analyses that are likely to be directionally similar confirmation biases. That is, the power analysis is not for the full 2 x 4 mixed ANOVA design but for comparing two groups: a 2 (A 2 (Debiasing Technique: Control vs. Consider the Opposite [social norms] [psychoeducation]) x 2 (Article Type: Belief Inconsistent vs. Belief Consistent) mixed model ANOVA. To achieve 95% power for detecting an effect of f = .10 using a two-way mixed ANOVA, conservatively assuming a correlation of r = 0.15 between the repeated measures, 278 participants per group are required. We plan to overshoot this number slightly to allow for anticipated participant exclusions, and thus will aim to collect at least 300 participants per debiasing condition (1200 total).

Data collection will be terminated once at least 30 pro and 30 anti participants have been recruited for each topic area within each condition (see Table 1). We expect to exceed this goal slightly for some cells because of changes in participants attitudes from the pre-screening measure, and because of instances where an n is reached but there remain unfilled slots that were previously posted.

A reading time score will be calculated by subtracting reading time for belief-inconsistent articles from reading time for belief-consistent articles. Higher scores indicate greater selective exposure. Reading time scores will be collapsed across the three topic areas for all analyses.

Comparing the efficacy of debiasing strategies (RQ5). To examine whether the debiasing conditions differed in their effects, we will compare selective exposure and biased assimilation across the three experimental conditions (consider-the-opposite, social norms, psychoeducation). 
First, we will conduct a 3 x 2 mixed model ANOVA comparing article selection scores across the three conditions.  To test if the effect of article type is moderated by debiasing technique, we will conduct three 2 x 2 ANOVAs: 1) First, we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the consider-the-opposite and social norms conditions; 2) Second, we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the consider-the-opposite and psychoeducation conditions; 3) we will conduct a 2 (article type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing article scores between the psychoeducation and social norms conditions.
Then, we will conduct a 3 x 2 mixed model ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores across the three conditions. To test if the effect of study type is moderated by debiasing technique, we will conduct three 2 x 2 ANOVAs: 1) First, we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the consider-the-opposite and social norms conditions; 2) Second, we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the consider-the-opposite and psychoeducation conditions; 3) we will conduct a 2 (study type) x 2 (debiasing technique) ANOVA comparing biased assimilation scores between the psychoeducation and social norms conditions.
Finally, we will conduct a one-way omnibus ANOVA comparing reading time scores across the three conditions.  [Note: we will only conduct the following planned contrasts if the one-way ANOVA is significant]. A planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the consider-the-opposite vs. social norms condition; a planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the consider-the-opposite vs. psychoeducation condition; a planned contrast comparing reading time scores in the social norms vs. psychoeducation condition.

IVs: Debiasing (consider-the-opposite, social norms, and psychoeducation), Article type (belief-consistent vs. belief-inconsistent)

DVs: Selective Exposure (article selection and reading time), Biased Assimilation

attributes.title: Threat messages in Hate speech on Social media
attributes.description:
Empirical data suggests that social media platforms such as Twitter are strategically used by supporters of extremist ideologies to promote hate speech and facilitate radicalization processes, but underlying psychological mechanisms remain unclear. What is more, the impact of hate speech messages on Twitter users has to the best of my knowledge not yet been examined. The present project aims to provide a more nuanced picture of the content and impact of tweets with hate speech content on their readers by detecting systematic patterns. 

The project examines the following research questions:  
1.	Does hate speech on German twitter contain messages paint immigrants and Muslims as a symbolic, realistic or safety threat?
2.	How do these threat messages differ with regards to their content and wording?
3.	Does the prevalence of threat messages in hate speech predict readers’ reactions in form of likes?

The study will use two data subsets from the POLLY dataset which together contain over 40.000 German tweets collected in 2017 and wereas made publicly available for academic purposes by the researchers Jaki & De Smedt and has been anonymized in line with the EU’s new General Data Protection Regulation. 

Drawing on the concepts of Integrated Threat Theory, I expect content on German twitter, which is classified as hate speech, to contain significantly more threat perceptions than tweets which are not classified as hate speech. I also expect that the impact of these messages is reflected in form of an increased number of likes in comparison with tweet messages that are not classified as hate speech.

attributes.title: A CFA Model: Pornography Use, Social Media Use, Self-objectification and Body-Esteem
attributes.description: This is the study plan for my undergraduate thesis. The study is designed to use a SEM model to explore the causes of self-objectification and one of its psychological consequences.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1: For both men and women, higher social media use will predict higher self-objectification through higher appearance comparison, and in turn, predict lower body-esteem.
Hypothesis 2: For women, higher pornography use will predict higher self-objectification, and in turn, predict lower body-esteem. 
Hypothesis 3: For men, higher pornography use will not predict higher self-objectification, but higher self-objectification will predict lower body esteem.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A quantitative design was utilized to understand the relationship between social media use, pornography use, social comparison, self-objectification and body-esteem. We collected data from Amazon Mechanical Turk and will use an SEM model to address our research questions.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: The data has been collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk without any observation or access.

question.value: The data was collected on Amazon Mechanical Turk. In total, we collected 500 samples from people who are aged 18-35 and currently living in the US. When collecting, options including HyperBatch, Block Duplicate IP Addresses, Block Suspicious Geocode Locations and Verify Worker Country Location were selected. The Approval Rate was set from 95% to 100%. Each participant was awarded $0.50 after finalizing the survey. The collection was commenced on 04/06/20 at 3:30 AM (UTC) and completed on  4/10/2020 at 7:42:34 PM (UTC).

q11.value: We recruited 500 participants from Mechanical Turk. And after screening participants who failed to pass the two control questions, we'd like to see there will be more than 490 participants remained.

question.value:
Social media (Facebook) use: We created two scales to measure individuals’ frequency of Facebook usage. First, we created a scale assessing the general frequency of Facebook usage. Second, we created a scale assessing the extent of daily Facebook usage. We created six items to assess individuals’ general frequency of using Facebook. Participants were asked to choose a frequency on specific Facebook-related behaviors (e.g., “Approximately how often do you check your Facebook?”) on 6 frequency choices ( “less than once a week”, “once a week”, “less than 7 times a week”, “once a day”,  “2-4 times a day”, "more than 5 times a day"). The 4-item daily frequency of Facebook usage scale assessed individuals’ daily frequency of using Facebook. Participants were asked to choose a frequency on how much they had spent engaging in  Facebook-related behaviors in the past day (e.g., “In the past day, approximately how much time have you spent on Facebook?”) on 6 frequencies choices (“less than 30 minutes”, “31-60 minutes”, “1-2 hours”, “2-3 hours”,  “3-6 hours”, "more than 6 hours").

Pornography use: The seven-item frequency subscale of the Pornography Use Scale (Szymanski & Stewart-Richardson, 2014) was used to assess frequency of pornography use. Sample items include “Taken together, how many hours per week do you view 260 MIKORSKI AND SZYMANSKI sexually explicit/pornographic material (such as magazines, movies, and/or Internet site)?” and “When using/viewing sexually explicit/pornographic materials (including online, magazines, DVD/videos/movies) in one sitting, I spend approximately X amount of time doing such,” Response options vary (e.g., none,once a month or less, 2 or 3 days a month, 1 or 2 days a week, 3 to 5 days a week, every day or almost every day).

Appearance Comparison: Physical Appearance Comparison Scale-Revised (Schaefer & Thompson, 2014). This 11-item measure assesses individuals’ tendency to compare their appearance with others. Participants were asked to indicate the frequency of certain thoughts and behaviors (e.g., "When I’m out in public, I compare my physical appearance to the appearance of others.") on a 5-point scale (0-never to 4-always).

Self-objectification: Objectified Body Consciousness Scale (McKinley & Hyde, 1996). Participants were asked to indicate their agreement to items (e.g., “I would be ashamed for people to know what I really weigh”) on a 7-point scale (1 - strongly disagree to 7 - strongly agree).

Body-esteem: Body Esteem Scale (Mendelson, Mendelson & White, 2001). Participants were asked to indicate the frequency of certain thoughts and beliefs of their body (e.g., "Other people consider me good-looking.") on a 5 point scale(0-never to 4-always).

Every variable will be calculated into a weighted score with the factor loadings.
We will use an SEM model to analyze our data. The hypothetical model is shown in the graph below.

q20.value: Participants who failed to pass the two control questions (e.g., "This is a control question, please select 1.") will be excluded from the data. Participants who missed more than 5% of the questions will be excluded from the data.

q21.value: The remaining missing data will be supplimented by the R package MICE.

attributes.title: Exploring the Relationship between Episodic Fluency, Gambling, and Risky Behaviors in College Students

q1.value: Exploring the Relationship between Episodic Fluency and Risky Tendencies in College Students

q3.value: The objective of this project is to explore underlying cognitive factors associated with risk taking and risky behavior. We will examine the role that the consideration for future consequences may play in future-oriented decisions by testing cognitive ability to “mentally time travel” and propensity for impulsive behavior. It may be that individuals who cannot as vividly envision themselves in realistic future scenarios are also more inclined to make impulsive decisions in the present because the potential consequences are not as available. In this second experiment, we assess students’ ability to mentally simulate past and future events (mental simulation fluency), phenomenological experience of these events, as well as measures of optimism, impulsivity, and resilience. In this way, we hope to determine how the ability to mentally simulate future-oriented thoughts may be related to the propensity to engage in risky behaviors.

q4.value:
Mental simulation fluency:
Main effect of valence: Participants will generate more positive than negative events (Noël, Saeremans, Kornreich, Jaafari, & D’Argembeau, 2017).
Main effect of temporal distance: Participants will generate more close than distant events (Jarvis & Miller, 2016). 
We do not anticipate any 2-way interactions; however we predict a three way interaction between temporal distance, valence, and event type as observed by D’Argembeau and Linden, (2004). Although no three-way interactions were observed in Experiment 1, we retain this hypothesis in order to test it in a different sample. 

Phenomenological experience of events:
Main effect of valence: Participants will report a more detailed representation of positive than negative events through ratings of sensory and contextual details (D’Argembeau & Linden, 2004; Noel et al. 2017). 
Main effect of temporal distance: Participants will generate a more detailed representation of close than distant events through ratings of sensory and contextual details (D’Argembeau & Linden, 2004; Noel et al. 2017).
Main effect of event type: Participants will generate a more detailed representation (as measured by rating of sensory and contextual details) of past than future events (D’Argembeau & Linden, 2004).
Positive events will be associated with higher scores on the dependent variables measuring autonoetic consciousness-feeling as though you are experiencing your mental simulation/feeling as though you are travelling in time when you mentally simulate an event (Noel et al. 2017). 

Relationship between mental time travel and risk taking:
We predict a negative correlation between mental time travel ability and propensity for risky behavior such that:
Those who generate fewer episodic events will have lower scores on optimism (LOT-R, Scheier et al. 1994).		 	 	 		
Those who generate fewer episodic events will have higher scores on impulsivity (FDIS, Dickman, 1990).
Those who generate fewer episodic events will have lower scores on resiliency (BRS, Smith et. al, 2008).
We predict a negative correlation between depression score and number of negative events generated, such that participants who score higher in depression (PHQ-9, Spitzer, Kroenke, & Williams, 1999) should generate more negative events (future and past).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: In each group, all participants were exposed to each level of the within-subjects aspect of the experiment in a random order. Neither experimenters nor participants were aware of the order in which they progressed through the time frame conditions of the experiment.

question.value: This experiment is a 2x2x2 repeated measures factorial design. The experiment measures cognitive ability to mentally time travel by manipulating event-type (past vs. future), valence (positive vs. negative), and temporal distance (year vs. 5/10 years). Each participant will be exposed to all 8 levels of the within-subject factors of the experiment. Additionally, each participant will complete a survey containing measures of demographic information, optimism, impulsivity, resilience, and depression.

q9.value: We will use randomization of the conditions such that the OpenSesame program generates a random order of presentation of the mental simulation tasks for each participant. In addition, the survey program contains a series of surveys which assess basic demographics, a brief medical history, optimism, resilience, impulsivity, and depression. For the survey program, demographics is always assessed first. The depression scale is always administered last to avoid severely altering the mood of the participants before completing other surveys. The remaining surveys are presented in a randomized order. In addition, the survey and fluency tasks are counterbalanced, with approximately half of the participants completing the survey first and the other half completing the fluency task first.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data has been downloaded from computers used to complete data collection and compiled into a single drive folder, but no analysis has been done.

question.value: Our participants consist of students at Willamette University who were enrolled in Fall 2019 and Spring 2020 Introduction to Psychology courses, and received credit for the research requirement of the course in exchange for participation.

For each mental time travel task, we manipulated event-type (past vs. future), valence (positive vs. negative), and temporal distance (year vs. 5/10 years) for a total of 8 combinations of the task. For example, a task that uses future/positive/week would ask participants to imagine positive events that could happen next week and list as many of these events as they can think of in 60 seconds. Each participant is exposed to each of the 8 levels one time.

Basic demographics including age, gender, and years of education will be assessed. 

Participants will also complete brief medical history in which they will report vision ability, hearing ability, history of stroke or brain injury, and medications that could possibly alter cognition. 

To measure fluency of future and past-oriented thoughts, we will measure the number of events generated by the participant for each level. 

To measure phenomenological characteristics of thought, participants will be instructed to select the first specific event generated from each of the 8 categories. Phenomenological characteristics includes both sensory-contextual qualities and autonoetic experience. 

Participants will rate their subjective experience of each event using a 7-point scale derived from the Memory Characteristics Questionnaire (Johnson, Foley, Suengas, & Raye, 1988). 				
‘My representation of this event involves visual details: 1 = none, 7 = a lot’ 
‘My representation of this event involves other sensory details (sound, odours, taste): 1 = none, 7 = a lot’
‘My representation of the location where the event takes place is: 1 = not at all clear, 7 = extremely clear’
‘My representation of the people and objects involved is : 1 = not at all clear, 7 = extremely clear’ 
‘While imagining the event, I feel as though I am experiencing it: 1 = not at all, 7 = completely’
‘While imagining the event, I feel that I travel forward to the time when it would happen: 1 = not at all, 7 = completely’

To assess optimism, participants will complete the Life Orientation Test-Revised (LOT-R, Scheier et al. 1994) which assesses dispositional optimism.

To assess impulsivity, participants will complete the Dickman Functional and Dysfunctional Impulsivity Survey which assesses impulsivity on two levels: 1) the tendency to act with less forethought than those of equal ability (dysfunctional impulsivity) and 2) the tendency to act with little forethought when this is optimal (functional impulsivity) (FDIS, Dickman, 1990).

To assess resilience, participants will complete the Brief Resilience Scale which assesses the ability to “bounce back” or recover from stress (BRS, Smith et. al, 2008).
To assess depression, participants will complete the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9, Spitzer, Kroenke, & Williams, 1999).

A total fluency score for each participant will be computed by summing the total number of events generated across all conditions. 
We will take the mean of the first four questions about phenomenological experience to create a single measure of sensory-contextual qualities of mental simulations.
We will take the mean of the last two questions about phenomenological experience to create a single measure of autonoetic consciousness.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse mental fluency. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative) and the dependent variable is fluency, or number of events generated.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse ratings of sensory and contextual details. The within subjects aspect is time frame, which consist of the following variables: event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative). The dependent variable is the average rating of sensory and contextual details, which is represented by a mean score of sensory and contextual detail ratings for each time frame level.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse ratings of autonoetic consciousness between older and younger adults. The within subjects aspect is time frame, which consist of the following variables: event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative). The dependent variable is the average rating of autonoetic consciousness, which is represented by a mean score of autonoetic consciousness ratings for each time frame level.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and optimism for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and impulsivity for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and resilience for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and optimism.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and impulsivity.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and resilience.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for statistical tests. We will also use Bonferroni corrections to avoid inflating Type 1 errors. If we get null effects, we will use Bayesian analysis to see if there is evidence that there is no difference between factors.

q22.value:
We will calculate mean reaction times for follow up questions on phenomenological experience. If participants move through the questions too quickly (by 2 standard deviations or more), their answers will not be included in data analysis. 

Participants who do not appear to have completed the personality measures seriously (as indicated by reverse coding of some of the questions) will be excluded from the data.

We will exclude any participant that scores a depression score of 14 or higher on the Patient Health Questionnaire-9.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete both the mental time travel task and the risk tasking measures, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory tests to observe the relationship between our risk taking measures (optimism, resilience, impulsivity).

‘My representation of this event involves other sensory details (sound, odours, taste): 1 = none, 7 = a lot’
‘My representation of the location where the event takes place is: 1 = not at all clear, 7 = extremely clear’
‘My representation of the people and objects involved is : 1 = not at all clear, 7 = extremely clear’ 
‘While imagining the event, I feel as though I am experiencing it: 1 = not at all, 7 = completely’
‘While imagining the event, I feel that I travel forward to the time when it would happen: 1 = not at all, 7 = completely’

To assess optimism, participants will complete the Life Orientation Test-Revised (LOT-R, Scheier et al. 1994) which assesses dispositional optimism.

To assess impulsivity, participants will complete the Dickman Functional and Dysfunctional Impulsivity Survey which assesses impulsivity on two levels: 1) the tendency to act with less forethought than those of equal ability (dysfunctional impulsivity) and 2) the tendency to act with little forethought when this is optimal (functional impulsivity) (FDIS, Dickman, 1990).

To assess resilience, participants will complete the Brief Resilience Scale which assesses the ability to “bounce back” or recover from stress (BRS, Smith et. al, 2008).
To assess depression, participants will complete the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9, Spitzer, Kroenke, & Williams, 1999).

A total fluency score for each participant will be computed by summing the total number of events generated across all conditions. 
We will take the mean of the first four questions about phenomenological experience to create a single measure of sensory-contextual qualities of mental simulations.
We will take the mean of the last two questions about phenomenological experience to create a single measure of autonoetic consciousness.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse mental fluency. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative) and the dependent variable is fluency, or number of events generated.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse ratings of sensory and contextual details. The within subjects aspect is time frame, which consist of the following variables: event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative). The dependent variable is the average rating of sensory and contextual details, which is represented by a mean score of sensory and contextual detail ratings for each time frame level.

We will use a 2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA to analyse ratings of autonoetic consciousness between older and younger adults. The within subjects aspect is time frame, which consist of the following variables: event type (past, future), temporal distance (year, 5/10 years), and valence (positive, negative). The dependent variable is the average rating of autonoetic consciousness, which is represented by a mean score of autonoetic consciousness ratings for each time frame level.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and optimism for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and impulsivity for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between fluency and resilience for both positive and negative events.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and optimism.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and impulsivity.

We will use Pearson correlation coefficients to analyze the relationship between autonoetic consciousness and resilience.
